docs.lead_paragraph: The night she calls ''the children's riot,'' was a turning point for Cristina Rathbone. She was living in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, when she found herself in a liquor store among dusty, overpriced bottles, watching a retarded man flee a beating by a group of prepubescent boys. The man used the store as a sanctuary, and the door was locked against the boys throwing bricks and bottles. ''They were so small,'' Ms. Rathbone said. ''They hadn't started shaving, and they had these high, baby voices. But they were the same boys who called me names as I walked to and from the subway. I realized that I, like a lot of New Yorkers, was becoming afraid of young people. I asked myself, who are these kids?''

headline.main: Writer's Troubling Look at Face of Troubled Youth

docs.abstract: Interview with Cristina Rathbone, 32-year-old journalist and author of book about inner city high school students; her book, On the Outside Looking In: A Year at an Inner City High School, is based on her experience spending academic year at West Side High School in midtown Manhattan, exploring lives of its poor black and Hispanic students; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Using Gifts as Bait, Peru Sterilizes Poor Women'' (front page, Feb. 15): That two woman may have died and hundreds more suffered serious health consequences since 1995 is an inexcusable tragedy. Meanwhile, nearly 2,000 women a year die from pregnancy-related causes in Peru. At least 400 deaths are due to abortion, which is severely restricted by law, forcing women to practice it clandestinely and under unsafe conditions.
docs.abstract: Susan Wood letter says that while it is tragic that some women in rural Peru have suffered and two have died from botched sterilizations, at least 400 women in country die each year from botched abortions (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Long after a woman has given birth, cells from her fetus may still circulate in her blood stream, and a new study being reported today has linked those cells to development of a disease in the mother years after pregnancy. The disease is scleroderma, a so-called autoimmune disorder in which the body mysteriously attacks its own healthy tissues. For equally mysterious reasons, scleroderma strikes women four times as often as men.

headline.main: Cells of Fetus Could Link Some Mothers To a Disease

docs.abstract: New study reports that long after a woman has given birth, cells from her fetus may still circulate in her blood stream, and those cells are linked to development of disease, scleroderma, in mother years after pregnancy; scleroderma is so-called autoimmune disorder in which body mysteriously attacks its own healthy tissue; study finds that women with scleroderma have fetal cells in their blood decades after pregnancy more often and in larger numbers that mothers who did not have condition (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Saying they have finally found a cheap way for developing nations to use the drug AZT to reduce mother-to-infant transmission of the AIDS virus, Government health officials announced yesterday that they were suspending the use of dummy pills in a series of controversial overseas experiments on pregnant women. The announcement, by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, left people on both sides of the debate elated, but for different reasons.

headline.main: Placebo Use Is Suspended In Overseas AIDS Trials

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, citing findings that $80 worth of AZT given during last four weeks of pregnancy could cut mother-to-infant transmission of AIDS virus in half, halts use of placebos in series of controverisal overseas studies on pregnant women; infected pregnant women in United States are routinely given longer, far more costly AZT regimen that cuts risk of transmission by two-thirds (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A United Nations survey of 152 countries has found that the United States is one of only six that does not have a national policy requiring paid maternity leave. Such disparate countries as the Sudan, Cameroon, and Nepal, for example, mandate that a woman receive her salary while she is caring for her newborn. The majority of countries surveyed provide benefits through social welfare systems, some require the employer to pay, and still others combine both financing sources.

headline.main: U.N. Surveys Paid Leave For Mothers

docs.abstract: United Nations survey of 152 nations finds United States is one of only six that does not have national policy requiring paid maternity leave; says majority of nations surveyed provide benefits through social welfare systems, some require employer to pay and others combine both financing sources; finds women contribute half or more of family income in some 30 percent of households in nations studied, compared with 55 percent in United States and 59 percent in Europe (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The idea was around even before 1886, when the Salvation Army announced its very first home for unwed mothers: ''The Rescue Home for the fallen and the falling is now opened for young women who desire and are earnestly seeking the salvation of their bodies and souls.'' The tone is surely different at Project Peace in Montclair, where J. C., a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology, recently talked about keeping appointments with her therapist and reporting to her new job as a retail supervisor. ''I've got to get used to living with a bunch of women,'' she said, having lived on her own for three years after high school and having shared an apartment with her boyfriend in Manhattan after college.

headline.main: No Shame, but Plenty of Need, at Home for Unwed Mothers

docs.abstract: Article profiles Project Peace, home for unwed mothers in Montclair, NJ; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dark rumors and conspiracy theories about the death of Diana, the Princess of Wales, began circulating almost as soon as the car she was riding in crashed in Paris last year. Now, Mohamed al-Fayed, whose son, Dodi, was also killed in the accident, has publicly endorsed one of the most provocative theories, declaring he believes that the two were murdered by ''people who did not want Diana and Dodi to be together.'' ''I believe 99.9 percent that it was no accident,'' Mr. Fayed told The Mirror, a tabloid newspaper here, this week. ''There was a conspiracy, and I will not rest until I have established exactly what happened.'' He offered no further details or evidence to support the charge.

headline.main: Now Murder Is Suggested In the Death Of Diana

docs.abstract: Mohamed al-Fayed, whose son, Dodi, died in Paris car crash with Diana, Princess of Wales, backs theory that couple was murdered, newspaper interview; her family and Buckingham Palace score stand (M)
